name: 3-thiaheptane
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: The basic unit for 3-thiaheptane can be considered as butane which has a melting point of -138.3 degrees Celsius. Each additional methylene group (CH2) in the alkane series typically increases the melting point by about 20 degrees Celsius. In 3-thiaheptane, there are two additional methylene groups added to butane, which would contribute an increase of 40 degrees Celsius. The sulfur atom (thia group) replacing a methylene group is larger and more polarizable than carbon, which generally increases the melting point through stronger van der Waals forces. Assuming the sulfur contributes a similar increase as a methylene group, the total increase would be around 40 degrees Celsius from the base butane value.
Test (Predicted reason):
- Basic unit, methane has a melting point of -182. The thiaheptane molecule has a sulfur atom which is larger and more polarizable than a hydrogen atom, which would increase the melting point due to stronger van der Waals forces.
- The addition of a sulfur atom to the molecule increases the molecular weight and the polarizability of the molecule, which generally increases the melting point.
- The presence of a five-carbon chain (pentane) in the molecule also increases the melting point due to increased van der Waals interactions.
- The thiaheptane molecule has a strained, non-planar structure which can lead to a higher melting point due to the increased rigidity of the molecule.
- The presence of a double bond in the molecule can slightly lower the melting point due to less efficient packing in the solid state.
- The overall molecular structure and the presence of a sulfur atom contribute to a higher melting point than the basic methane molecule.
